editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A match at midnight. A pleasant comedy: as it hath been acted by the children of the revels.
London: printed by Aug. Mathewes, for William Sheares, and are to be sold at his shop in Britain's burse. 1633.

list.item: Jarvis, the widow's husband disguised like her servant.

div.head: A match at midnight.
Actus primus. Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter as making themselves ready, Tim bloodhound, and Sim the man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Good morrow master Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Morrow Sim, my father stirring Sim?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not yet I think, he heard some ill news of your brother Alexander last night, that will make him lie an hour extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum, I am sorry the old man should lie by the hour, but o, these wicked elder brothers, that swear refuse them, and drink nothing but wicked sack, when we swear nothing but niggers noggers , make a meal of a bloat herring, water it with four shillings beer, and then swear we have dined as well as my lord mayor.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Here was goody Finne the fishwoman fetched home her ring last night.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ye should have put her money by herself, for fear of wronging of the whole heap.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: So I did sir and washed it first in two waters.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: All these petty pawns sirrah, my father commits to my managing, to instruct me in this craft, that when he dies, the commonwealth may want a good member.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, you are cursed as much as he already.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: O brother, 'tis well you are up.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why, why?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Now you shall see the dainty widow, the sweet widow, the delicate widow, that tomorrow morning must be our mother in law.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What the widow nag.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yes, yes, she that dwells in Blackfriars, next to the sign of the fool laughing at a feather.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: She, she, good brother make yourself handsome, for my father will bring her hither presently.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: niggers noggers , I thought he had been sick and had not been up Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why so did I too, but it seems the widow took him at a better hand, and raised him so much the sooner.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: While I tie my band, prithee stroke up my foretop a little, niggers, and I had but dreamt of this an hour before I waked, I wood have put on my Sunday clothes, 'snailes my shoes are as pale as the cheek of a stewed pander, a clout, a clout Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: More haste, the worse speed, here's never a clout now.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What's that lies by the books?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: This 'tis a summoner's coat.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Prithee lends a sleeve of that, had a noble on't last night, and never paid me my bill money.

div.stage: Enter old Bloodhound, the widow, her maid, and man.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Look, look upon, and ready, all ready widow is, he is in some deep discourse with Sim, concerning moneys out to one or another.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Has he said his prayers sir?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Prayer before providence, when did ye know any thrive, and swell that uses it, he's a chip o'th old block, I exercise him in the trade of thrift, by turning him to all the petty pawns, if they come to me, I tell 'em I have given over brokering, moiling for muck and trash, and that I mean to live a life monastic, a praying life, pull out the tail of Croesus from my pocket, and swear 'tis called charity's looking glass, or an exhortation to forsake the world.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Dainty hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: But let a fine fool that's well feathered come, and withal good meat, I have a friend it may be, that may compassionate his wants, I'll tell ye an old saw for't over my chimney yonder, a poor man seem to him that's poor, and prays thee for to lend, but tell the prodigal (Not quite spent) thou wilt procure a friend.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Trust me a thrifty saw.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Many will have virtuous admonitions on their walls, but not a piece in their coffers, give me these witty politic saws, and indeed my house is furnished with no other.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: How happy shall I be to wed such wisdom.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Shall bed it, shall bed it wench, shalt have't by infusion, look, look. Enter a smith.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Save ye master Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Who's this, goodman file the blacksmith, I thought 'had been our old collier: did you go to bed with that dirty face goodman file?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: And rise with it too sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What have you bumming out there goodman file?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: A vice sir, that I would fain be furnished with a little money upon't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why how will you do to work then goodman file?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: This is my spare vice, not that I live by.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum, ye did not buy this spare vice of a lean courtier, did ye?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: No sir, of a fat cook, that strained of a smith for's rent.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: O hard hearted man of grease.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Sim, we must do't sometimes.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha thrifty whoreson.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And what wood serve your turn goodman file?

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: A noble sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What upon a spare vice to lend a noble?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why sir, for ten groats you may make yourself drunk, and so buy a vice outright for half the money.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That is no noble vice I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: How long wood ye have it!

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: But a fortnight, 'tis to buy stuff I protest sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Look ye being a neighbour, and born one for another.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha villain, shalt have all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There is five shillings upon't, which at the fortnight's end goodman file you must make five shillings six pence.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: How sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay and it were not to do you a courtesy —

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha boy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And then I had forgotten three pence for my bill, so there is four pence, and nine pence, which you are to tender back, five shillings six pence, goodman file at the end of the fortnight.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Well and it were not for earnest necessity, hay boys, I come, I come, you black rascals, let the cans go round.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sim, because the man's an honest man, I pray lay up his vice, as safe as it were your own.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And if he miss his day, and forfeit, it shall be yours and your heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: What, disbursing money boy? here is thy mother in law

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Your nose drops, 'twill spoil her ruff.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pray forsooth — what's o'clock.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O fie upon him mistress, I thought he had begun to ask you blessing.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Peace, we'll have more on't. Walks towards him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I wonot kiss indeed.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: And he wonot, here are those that will forsooth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Get ye in you rogue.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I hope ye will sir? I was bred in Ireland where the women begin the salutation.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I wonot kiss truly.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Indeed you must.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Wood my girdle may break if I do.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I have a mind.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: niggers noggers I wonot.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay nay, now his great oath's past, there's no talk on't, I like him never the worse, there's an old stitchwell sort,
sp.l: A kiss first, next the feeling sense,
Crack say the purse strings, out fly the pence.
sp.p: But he can talk though, whose boy are you Tim?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Your boy forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Can ye turn and wind a penny Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Better than yourself forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: You have looked in the church book late, how old are you Tim?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Two and twenty years, three months , three days, and three quarters of an hour, forsooth father.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: He has arithmetic.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And Grammer too, what's Latin for your head Tim?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Caput.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: But what for the head of a block?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Caput blockhead.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Do ye hear, your ear.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Aura.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Your eye.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Occules.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: That's for one eye, what's Latin for two.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Occulies, occulies.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: An admirable accidental grammarian I protest sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: This boy shall have all, I have an elder rogue that sucks and draws me, a tavern academician: one that protests to whores, and shires with highway lawyers; an arrant unclarified rogue, that drinks nothing but wicked sack.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Here's a gentleman would speak with you,

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Look, look, now he's come for more money.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: A very hopeful house to match into wench, the father a knave, one son a drunkard, and tother a fool.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O monster father, look if he be not drunk, the very sight of him makes me long for a cup of six.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pray father, pray to God to bless me.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Look, look, takes his brother for his father.

sp.speaker: Sim:
sp.p: Alas sir, when the drink's in, the wit's out, and none but wise children know their own fathers.

sp.speaker: Tim:
sp.p: Why I am none of your father, brother, I am Tim, do ye know Tim.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Yes, umph — for a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: How wild he looks: good sir we'll take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p:
Shalt not go faith widow: you cheater rogue, must I ha' my friends frighted out my house by you, look he'll steal
nothing to feast his bawds, get ye out sirrah, there are constables, beadles, whips, and the college of extravaging, yclept Bridewell ye rogue, ye rogue there is, there is — mark that.

sp.speaker: Alexander.
sp.p: Can you send me a mark upon this ring sir, and there set it down in your book, and umph — mark that.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I'll have no stolen rings, picked out of pockets, or taken upon the way, not I.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I'll give you an old saw for't.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: There's a rogue mocks his father, sirrah, get 'Ye gone, Sim, go let lose the mastiff.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Alas sir, he'll tear and pull out your son's throat.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Better pull't out, than a halter stretched, away out of my doors rogue, I defy thee.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Must you be my mother in law?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: So your father says sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You see the worst of your eldest son, I abuse nobody .

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: The rogue will fall upon her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I will tell ye an old saw.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray let's hear it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: An old man is a bed full of bones,
And who can it deny,
By whom (Umph) a young wench lies and grieves,
For better company.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Did ye ever hear such a rascal? come come, let's leave him: I'll go buy thy wedding ring presently, you're best be gone sirrah: I am going for the constable, I and one of the churchwardens, and now I think on't, he shall pay five shillings to the poor for being drunk, twelve pence shall go into the box, and tother four, my partner and we'll share betwixt us, there's a new path to thrift wench, we must live, we must live girl.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And at last die for altogether.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis a diamond.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: You'll be at the fountain after dinner?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: White, 'twill run boy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Here's a noble now, and I'll bring you tother as I come
by to the tavern, but I'll make you swear, I shall drink nothing but small beer.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Niggers naggers thou shalt not, there's thine own oath for thee, thou shalt eat nothing and thou wilt, but a poached spider, and drive it down with syrup of toads. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ah, prithee Sim bid the maid eat my breakfast herself.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Has turned his stomach, for all the world like a Puritans, at the sight of a surplice, but your breakfast shall be devoured by a stomach of a stronger constitution I warrant you. Exit.

div.stage: Enter captain Carvegut, and lieutenant bottom.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: No game abroad this morning, this coxcomb park, I think be passed the best, I have known the time the bottom twixt these hills has been better fledged.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Look out captain, there's matter of employment at foot o'th hill.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A business?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes, and hopeful, there's a morning bird, his flight it seems for London, he hallows and sings sweetly, prithee let us go and put him out of tune.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thee and I have crotchets in our pates, and thou knowest two crotchets make one quaver, he shall shake fort. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Did her not see her true loves,
As her came from London,
O, if her saw not her fine brave loves,
Randall is quite undone,
sp.p:
Well, was never mortal man in Wales, could have waged praver, finers, and nimblers, than Randalls have done, to get service in London's: whoop, where was her now, just upon a bridge of stone, between the legs of a couple of pretty hills, but no more near mountains in Wales, than Clim of the Clough's bow, to her cousin David's harp, and now her prattle of Davie, I think yonder come prancing down the hills from Kingston a couple of her
tother cozens saint Nicholas clerks. the morning was so red as an egg, and the place very full of dangers, perils, and bloody businesses by reports: augh her swords was drawn, God pless us and her cozen Hercules was not stand against too, which shall her take if they take Randalls, will rip Randalls cuts out, and then Randalls shall see Paul's steeples no more, therefore her will go directly under the bridge, here was but standing to knees in little fine cool fair waters, and begar if her have Randalls out, her shall come and fetch Randalls and her will, were her nineteen Nicholas clerks. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Which way took he?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: On straight I think.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then we should see him man, he was just in mine eye when we were at foot o'th hill, and to my thinking stood here looking towards us upon the bridge.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So thought I, but with the cloud of dust we raised about us, with the speed our horses made: it seems we lost him, how I could stamp and bite my horse's ears off.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Let's spur towards Coomb house, he struck that way, sure he's not upon the road.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Sfoot if we miss him, how shall we keep our word with Sander Bloodhound in Fleetstreet after dinner at the fountain, he's out of cash, and thou knowest by cutter's law, we are bound to relieve one another.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Let's scour towards Coomb house, but if we miss him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No matter, dost see yonder barn o'th left hand?

sp.speaker: L●eu.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: At the West end, I tore a piece of board out,
And stuffed in close amongst the straw, a bag
Of a hundred pound at least, all in round shillings:
Which I made my last nights purchase for a lawyer.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Dost know the place to fetch it again?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: The torn board is my land mark, if we miss this,
We make for that, and whilst that lasts — o London,
Thou labyrinth that puzzleest strictest search,
Convenient inns of court, for highway lawyers,
How with rich wine, tobacco, and sweet wenches,
we will canvas thy dark case.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Away, let's spur. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Spur did her call her, have made Randalls stand without boots, in ferry pitiful pickles, but her will run as nimbles to London's, as greyhound after rabbits, and yet now her remember what her cozens talked, was some wiser and some too, Randalls heard talk of parne upon left hand, and a brave bag with hundred pounds in round shillings cod pless us, and yonder was Parnes and upon left hands too, now here was questions, and demands to be made, why Randalls should not rob them would rob Randalls, her will go to parnes, pluck away pords, pull out paggs, and show her cozen a round pair of heels, with all her round sillings, mark her now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: The rogue rise right, and has out stripped us this was staying in Kingston with our unlucky hostess, that must be dandled, and made drunk next her heart, she made us slip the very cream o'th morning, if any thing stand awkward, a woman's at one end on't.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, we have a hundred pieces good yet in the barn, they shall last us, and Saunder a month's mirth at least.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O these sweet hundred pieces, how I will kiss ye, and hug ye with that zeal a usurer does his bastard money, when he comes from church, wert not for them, where were our hopes, but come, they shall be sure to thunder in the taverns, I but now, just now I see pottle pots thrown down the stairs, just like sergeants and yeomen, one i'th neck of another.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Delicate vision. Exeunt. Ent. Ran.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p:
Her have got her page and awl by the hand, and her had ferrily thought in conscience, had not been so many round shillings in whole worlds but in Wales, 'twas time to supply her store, her had but thirteen pence half
penny in all the worlds, and that her have left in her little white purse, with a rope her find py the parne, just in the place her had this: Randalls will be no serving man's now, her will buy her brave parrells, brave swords, brave taggers, and prave ●eathers, and go a-wooing to brave comely pretty maids, rob Randalls, begar and her were ten dozens of cozens, Randalls rob her, mark her now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A plague of Friday mornings, the unfortunate day in the whole week.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Was ever the like sat, 'sfoot when I put it in I was so wary, though it were midnight, that I watched till a cloud had masked the moon, for fear she should have seen't.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O luck.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A gale of wind did but creep o'er the bottom, and because I heard things stir, I stayed, 'twas twelvescore passed me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: The pottle pots will sleep in peace tonight .

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And the sweet clinks.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: The clattering of pipes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The Spanish fumes.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: The more wine boy, the nimble anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: All tonight will be nothing, come we must shift, 'sfoot what a witty rogue 'twas to leave, this fair thirteen pence halfpenny, and this old halter, intimating aptly.
sp.l: Had the hangman met us three, by these presages,
Here had been his work, and here his wages.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Come, come, we must make friends. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: There sirrah, there's his bond, run into the strand, six weeks the tallow Chandler fetched my hundred markI lent him to set him up, and to buy grease, this is his day, I'll have his bones for't else, so pray tell him.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.p: But are a chandler's ones worth so much father?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Out coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Worth so much, I know my master will make dice on them, then 'tis but letting master Alexander carry them next Christmas to the temple, he'll make a hundred marks a night of them.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Mass that's true.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And run to master Eare-lack's the informer, in thieving lane, and ask him what he has done in my business he gets abundance, and if he carry my cause with one false oath, he shall have Moll, he will take her with a little, are ye gone sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: As ye come by Temple-bar, make a step to'th devil.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: To the devil father?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: My master means the sign of the devil.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And he cannot hurt ye fool, there's a saint holds him by the nose.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Sniggers, what does the devil and a saint both in a sign?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What a question's that, what does my master, and his prayer book a Sunday both in a pew?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, well, ye Gipsy, what do we both in a pew?

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.p: Why make a fair show, and the devil and the saint does no more.

sp.speaker: Blod.
sp.p: You're witty, you're witty, call to the man o'th house, bid him send in the bottles of wine tonight , they will be at hand i'th morning, — will ye run sir?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: To the devil as fast I can sir, the world shall know who's son I am. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.l: Let me see now, for a posy for the ring:
Never an end of an old saw, 'tis a quick widow Sim,
And wood have a witty posy.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: If she be quick, she's with child, whosoever got it you must father it, so that you come o'th nick, forth widow's quick, there's a witty posy for you quick widow ▪

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: No, no, I'll have one shall savour of, of a saw.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why then 'twill smell of the painted cloth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Let me see, a widow witty.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Is pastime pretty, put in that for the sport's sake.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: No, no, I can make the sport, than an old man.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Then will she answer, if you cannot a younger can,
And look, look sir, now I take of the younger,
Yonder's ancient young come over again, that
Mortgaged sixty pound per annum before he went,
I am deceived if he come not a day after the fair.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Mine almanac.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A prayer book sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: A prayer book for devote beggars I hate, look I beseech thee, fortune now befriend me, and I will call the plaguy whore in, let me see, six months.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes, 'tis he certain, this is a business must not be slackened sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Look I beseech thee, we shall have oat meal in our pottage six weeks after.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Four days too late Sim, four days too late Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Plums in our pudding a Sunday, plums in our pudding.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Master Bloodhound as I take it.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: You are a stranger sir, you shall be witness, I shall be railed at else, they will call me devil, I pray you how many months from the first of May, to the sixth of November following?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Six months and four days just.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I ask, because the last first of May, a noble gentleman, one ancient young.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: I am the man sir?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: My spectacles Sim, look Sim, is this ancient young?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Twas ancient young sir:

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And is't not ancient young?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No sir, you have made him a young ancient

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: O Sim, a chair, I know him now, but I shall not live to tell him.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: How fare ye sir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The better for you, he thanks you sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sick, sick, exceeding sick,

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: O'th sudden, strange.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A qualm of threescore years come over his stomach, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: That you beloved, you, who of all men i'th world, my poor heart doted on, whom I loved better than father, mother, brother, sister, uncles, ants, what wood ye have, that you should stay four days too late.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: I have your money ready,
And sir, I hope your old love to my father.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I am noble, fellow, very noble, a very rock of friendship, but, but, I had a house and barn burned down to the ground, since you were here.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: How burned ask Sim?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: By fire, sir, by fire.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: To build up which, for I am a poor man, a poor man, I was forced by course of law to enter upon your land, and so for less money than you had of me, I was fain to sell it to another, that by four days' stay, a man should lose his blood, our livings, our blood, o my heart, o my head.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Pray take it not so heinous, we'll go to him. I'll buy it again of him, he wonot be too cruel.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: A dog, a very dog, there is more mercy in a pair of unbribed bailiffs, to shun all such solicitings, he's rid to York, a very cutthroat rogue, but I'll send to him.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: A honest old man, how it moves him, this was my negligence, good Sim convey him into some warmer room, and I pray, however fortune, she that gives ever with the dexterity she takes, shall please to fashion out my sufferings, yet for his sake, my deceased father, the long friend of your heart, in your health, keep me happy.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: O right honest young man Sim.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sir, blood. Have I don't well?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The devil himself could not have don't better.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p:
I tell thee an old saw sirrah, he that dissembles in wealth shall not want, they say doom's day is coming, but think you not an't, this will make the pot seethe Sim,
good sir talk no more, my mouth runs over, sleep, wake, worthy beggar, worthy indeed to be one, and am one worthily — how fine it is to wanton without affliction, I must look out for fortunes, over again, no, I have money here, and 'tis the curse of merits, not to work, when she has money: there was a handsome widow, whose wild mad jealous husband died at sea, let me see, I am near Blackfriars, I'll have one start at her, or else —

div.stage: Enter Bloodhound, daughter Mol, with a bowl of beer.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: By my troth 'tis he captain Young's son, I have loved him even with languishings, ever since I was a girl but should I know it, I should run mad sure, what handsome gentlemen travail and manners makes, my father begun to ye sir, in a cup of final beer.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: How does he pray?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Pretty well now sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Mas 'tis small indeed — you'll pledge me?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Pray will ye tell me one thing?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: What is't.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Which is smaller, this beer, or your maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: The beer a great deal sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: I in quality.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: But not in quantity.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Let me try, and I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Will you tell me one thing before you try?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Which is smaller, this beer or your wit?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: O the beer, the beer.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: In quality.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes, in quantity.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Why then I pray keep your quantity of your wit, from the quality of my maidenhead, and ye shall find my maidenhead more than your wit.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: A witty maidenhead by this hand.

div.head: Actus. 2. Scaena 1.
div.stage: A table set out. Enter two servants, Jarvis and John, as to cover it for dinner.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Is my mistress ready for dinner?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Yes, if dinner be ready for my mistress.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Half an hour ago man.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: But prithee sir, is't for certain, for yet it cannot sink into my head, that she is to be married tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Troth, she makes little preparation, but it may be she wood be wedded, as she wood be bedded, privately.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Bedded call ye it, and she be bedded no better than he'll bed her, she may lie tantalized and eat wishes.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Pox on him, they say he's the arrantst 〈◊〉 , we shall never live good day with him.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Well, and she be s 〈…〉 ipt by threescore and ten, may she live sixscore and eleven, and repent twelve times a that's once an hour.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Set meat o'th board. Enter Wid.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why does your fellow grumble so?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I do not know.
They say you're to marry one that will feed us.
With horse-plums, instead of beef and cabbage.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And are you grieved at that?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: No, but my friends are.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: What friends are grieved?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: My guts.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: So it seems, you begone clown?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes, and shall conclude coxcomb, and I be fed with herring bones, 'Sfoot, I say no more, but if we do want as much bread of our daily allowance, as wood dine a sparrow, or as much drink as wood fox a fly, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And what do ye know sir?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Why, that there goes but a pair of sheets, a promoter, and a knave, if you know more, take your choice of either.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Tis well sir, set on dinner.

div.stage: Enter John with a rabbit in one hand, and a dish of eggs in another, and the maid.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: O mistress, yonder's the mad gallant, master Alexander Bloodhound entered into the hall.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Ye should have kept him out.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Alas, never a wench in town could do't he's so nimble, I had no sooner opened the door, but he thrust in ere I was aware. Enter Alex.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And how does my little handsome dainty, delicate, well-favoured, straight, and comely delicious bewitching widow.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: God's-foot here's one runs division before the fiddlers.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Sir, this is no seasonable time of visit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: 'Tis pudding time wench, pudding time, and a dainty time, dinner time my nimble eyed witty one, wilt be married tomorrow sirrah.Sets to table.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: She will be mad tomorrow sirrah.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What, art thou a fortune teller.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: A chip of the same block, a fool sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Good fool, give me a cup of cool beer.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Fill your master a cool cup of beer.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Pish, I spoke to the fool.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I thought y'had brought the fool with you sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Fool, 'tis my man, shalt sit i'faith wench,

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: For once I be as merry as you are mad, and learn fashions, I am set you see sir, but you must pardon sir our rudeness, Fridayes fare for myself, a dish of eggs and a rabbit, I looked for no stranger faces.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Strange, mine's a good face i'faith, prithee buss.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Why here's one comes to the business now.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sirrah, wilt have the old fellow?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Your father, yes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I tell thee thou shalt not, no, no, I have such —

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: There's but one raw bit sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Thy jester sure shall have a coat.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Let it be of your own cut sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, two to one is extremity — but as I was telling thee, I have such a husband for thee, so knowing, so discreet, so sprightly, fill a cup of claret, so; admirably, in desires so excellently, admirably deserving, that an old man, fie, fie, prithee — ha to thee.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: The man's mad sure.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Mad, by this hand, a witty gallant.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Prithee peace, shalt hear a song.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What copesmate's this trow, who let him in?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: By this light, a fellow of an excellent breeding.
He came unbidden, and brought his stool with him.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Look mistress, how they stare one at another?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Yes, and swell like a couple of gibed cats, met both by chance i'th dark, in an old garret.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Look, look, now there's no fear of the wild beasts, they have forgotten their spleens, and look prettily, they fall to their pasture, I had thought they had been angry, and they are hungry.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Are they none of Duke Humfrey's furies, do you think, that they devised this plot in Paul's to get a dinner?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Time may produce as strange a truth.
Let's note them.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Her loved her once, her loved her no more,
Saint Travis so well as her loved her then.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Another bar, this is the cook-maids leaving, open the door, and this is the daintiest dish she has sent in, a widgia in Welsh sauce — pray let's make a merry day on't.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: What do her keep open house, had her heard her was widows that dwelled here, are you widows good womans?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I want a husband sir.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p:
Angle Randalls comes in very good times, you
keep ordinaries her think, what have you set a cat before gallants there?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: They will eat him for the second course — these are suitors to my mistress sure, things that she sleights, set your fear boldly in, widows are not caught as maids kiss, faintly, but as mastiffs fight, valiantly.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Is her so, I pray bid her mistress observe Randalls for valours, and brave adventures?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Some beer.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Let them want nothing.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Here widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Some wine.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Here is wine for you sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Randalls will not be outbraved I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Here widow.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I thank you too sir,

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Sounds some metheglings here.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What does he call for?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Here are some eggs for you sir.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Eggs man, some metheglings, the wine of Wales.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Troth sir here's none i'th house, pray make a virtue of necessity, and drink to her in this glass of claret.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Well, because her will make a great deals of necessities of virtues, mark with what a grace Randalls will drink to her mistress.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: He makes at you forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Let him come, I have ever an English virtue to put by a Welsh.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: O noble widows, her heart was full of woes.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No noble Welshman, her heart was in her hose.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: 'Sounds, was that her manners to take away Randalls cups?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: No, it showed scurvy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Take't you at worst then.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Whelp of the devil, thou shalt see thy sire for't.

sp.speaker: John. Iar.
sp.l: Gentlemen what mean ye?

sp.speaker: Randals.
sp.p:
Let her come, let her come, Randalls will
redeem reputations her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Redeem your wit sir, first for you sir, you are a stranger, and see you, — but you, fie master Bloodhound.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Ha, Bloodhound, good sir let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Sounds, what do Randalls amongst bloodhounds, good widows lend her an ear.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Ancient young, how false our memories have played through long discontinuance, but why met here man, is Mars so bad a paymaster, that our ancients fight under Cupid's banner?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Faith this was but a sudden start begotten from distraction of some fortunes, I pursue this widow but for want of wiser work.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: The Welshman labours at it.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: A pair of a hundred of seepes, thirty brave cows, and twelve dozen of runts.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Twelve dozen of goose.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Give her but another hark?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: He has the mortgage still, and I have a handsome sister, do but meet at the fountain in Fleetstreet after dinner, o I will read thee a history of happiness, and thou shalt thank me.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Ay, read all's well, or weapons.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A word Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: O brave widows, her will meet her there, her know her times and her seasons, her warrant her, Randalls will make these brave gallants hang her selfes in those garters of willow garlands about her pates, mark her now, and remember. Exit.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Adieu sweet widow, for my ordinary —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Twas not so much worth sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: You mean, 'twere worth more then, and that's another handsomely begged.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You conclude women cunning beggars then.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes, and men good benefactors, my best wishes wait on so sweet a mistress — will ye walk? Exit.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I'll follow ye, wilt think on't soon at night, or not at all?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: I wood not have my wishes wronged, if I should bring it about handsomely, you can be honest?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Can, dost conclude me a sattin cheat?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: No, a smooth gallant sir, do not you fail to be here soon at nine, still provided, you will be honest, if I convey you not under her bed, throw me a top o'th tester, and lay me out o'th way like a rusty bilbo.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Enough, drink that, fare well, widow, fate, the destinies, and the three ill favoured sisters, have concluded the means, and when I am thy husband?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: I shall be your wife.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Do but remember these cross capers, than ye pitter sweet one?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Till then adieu ye bitter sweet one.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: This dinner would have showed better in bed-lane, and she a tother side, holdeth her whole nest of suitors play, what art decks the dark labyrinth of a woman's heart. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Marry old Earelack, is my father mad?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are both a concluding on't yonder, to morrow's the day, one wedding dinner must serve both marriages.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O Sim, the ancient, the delicate ancient there's a man, and thou talkest of a man, a good face and sparkling eye, a strength body, a delicate hand, a clean leg and foot, ah sweet Sim, there's a man worth, maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: But I say, master Earelack the old man, a foot like a bear, a leg like a bedstaff, a hand like a hatchet, an eye like a pig, and a face like a winter pigmy, there's a man for a maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: O look, look, o alas what shall I do with him?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
What, why what shall fifteen do with sixty and twelve, make a screen of him, stand next the fire,
whilst you sit behind him, and keep a friend's lips warm, many a wench would be glad of such a fortune.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Your oath struck it dead then? O my sides.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Five hundred deep of your side i'faith father.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Moll, come hither Moll, I hope Sim has discovered the project?

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: And tomorrow must be the day Moll, both of a day, one dinner shall serve, we may have store of little ones, we must save for our family.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Good sir, what rashness was parent to this madness, marry an old man — Earelack the informer?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Madness — you're a whore.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Is she a whore Sim?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She must be your wife, I tell —

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: An arrant whore, to refuse master innocent Earelack of Rogue-land, that for his dwelling, next that he doth inform now and then against enormities, and hath been blanketed, it may be pumped in's time: yet the world knows, he dost not out of need, he's of mighty means, but takes delight now and then to trot up and down, to avoid idleness, you whore.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Pray father.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: This wound wants oil, good sir in all my paths
I will make you my guide, I was only startled,
And with the suddenness of the word marriage
In that I knew, that this deserving gentleman
And I, had never so much conference,
Whereby this coal of Paphos, by the rhetoric
Of his love-stealing heart, captivating language,
Might be blown into a flame.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Does she take tobacco father?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: No, no, man, here are out of ballads,
She has all the garland of good will by heart.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Snails she may sing me asleep a nights than Sim

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, right sir, and then 'tis but tickling you o'th forehead with her heels, you are awake again, and never the worse man.

sp.speaker: Moll
sp.l: Is he but five years older than yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Nay, I want a week and three days of that too.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I'll tell thee an old saw for't girl, old, say he be, old blades are best, young hearts are never old.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Ah hay.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Gold is great glee, gold begets rest, what fault is found in gold?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will answer presently sir, with another saw.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Let's have't, let's have't.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Mark Moll.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Young, say she be young, young mutton's sweet, content is above gold, if like an old cock he with young mutton meets, he feeds like a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: A very pretty pithy one, I protest, look and Moll d'ye not laugh, shalt have a pair of gloves for thee, what leather dost love?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Calf sir, sheep's too simple for me.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis a witty notable knave, he should never serve me else.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: My mistress remembers her love, and requests you would endure her so much to your patience, as to read that.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Love letters, love lies, dost mark Sim, these women are violent, Sim, whilst I read the lie, do you rail to him upon the brewer, swear has deceived us, and save a cup of beer by't.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will save you a cup at that rate sir.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: I can make thee a hundred a year jointure wench, at the first indeed, I began with petty businesses wench, and here I picked, and there I picked, but now I run through none but things of value.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Sir, many thoughts trouble me, and your words carry such weight, that I will choose a time, when I have nothing else to do, to think on 'em.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: By my troth, she talks the wittiliest, and I wood understand her.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: O nimble, nimble widow, I am sorry we have no better friends, but pray commend me, though in a blunt dry commendations at the time and place appointed, I wonot fail, I know she has a nest of suitors, and would carry't close, because she fears surprisal.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: What news father?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Shalt lie there all night son.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Was that the first news I heard on't.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I must meet a friend i'th dark soon, let me see, we lovers are all a little mad, do you and Moll take a turn or two i'th garden, whilst Sim and I go up into the garret and device, the guess come.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: He's a little mad, and I had best hang him upon the cross beam in the garret. Exit.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: Come Moll, come Molkin, we'll even to the camomile bed, and talk of household stuff, and be sure thou remember'st a trade.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Please ye go before sir?

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: Nay, an old ape has an old eye, I shall go before, and thou wilt show me a love-trick, and lock me into the garden, butterflies, I will come discreetly behind Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Out upon him, what a suitor have I got, I am sorry you are so bad an archer sir.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: Why bird, why bird?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Why, to shoot at butts, when you should use prick-shafts, short shooting will lose ye the game, I allow 〈◊〉 you sir.

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.p: Her mind runs sure upon a Fletcher, or a bowyer, howsoever, I'll inform against both the Fletcher, for taking whole money for piec't arrows, the bowyer for horning the head men of his parish, and taking money for his pains. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter in the tavern, Alex. the captain, lieutenant, sue Shortheeles, a whore, mistress cook, a bawd.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Some rich canary boy.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Possible thus cheated of a hundred pieces, a handsome halter, and the hangman's wages popped in the place, what an acute witness we have in wickedness.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: 'Tis done, and handsomely you.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here's a pottle of rich canary, and a quart of neat claret gentlemen, and there's a gentleman below, he says he is your brother, master Bloodhound, he appointed to meet you here.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The expected thing that bought the Bristol stone.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Send him up prithee, remember how it must be carried?

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.p: I am her grandmother, forget not that by any means.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And pray remember that you do not mumble as if you were chewing bacon, and spoil all.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And hark.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Are these the company sir?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes, but those I like not, these are not they, I'll stay i'th next room till my company come.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Where you please sir, pray follow me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I hear him coming up gingerly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: O he tramples upon the bosom of a tavern with that dexterity, as your lawyers clerks do to Westminster hall upon a dirty day with a pair of white silk stockings, brother Tim, why now you're a man of your word I see.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay I love to be as good as my say, see brother, look, there's the rest or your money upon the ring, I cannot spend a penny, for I have never a penny left, what are these, what are these?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Gallants of note and quality, he that fits taking
Tobacco is a captain, captain Carvegut.

sp.speaker: Tim
sp.l: He will not make a capon of me, will he.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Are you not my brother?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: He that powers out that sparkling sprightly
Claret, is a lieutenant under him, lieutenant Bottom .
He was a sergeant first.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Of the poultry, or of Woodstreet.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Of the poultry, of a woodcock:
A sergeant in the field, a man of blood.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I'll take my leave brother, I am in great haste.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: That delicate sweet young gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Fough this tobacco.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: That bears the blush of morning upon her cheeks, whose eyes are like a pair of talking twins.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: She looks lust upon me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I think you are in haste.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No, no, no pray:

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Whose lips are beds of roses, betwixt which
There steals a breath sweeter then Indian spices.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Sweeter than ginger.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But then to touch those lips — you stay too long sure.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pish I tell you, I do not, I know my time, pray what's her name?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But 'tis descended from the Grecian steam, the great tribute Lindabride's her name, that ancient marron is her reverent Granham.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Niggers I have read of her in the mirror of knighthood.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Come they shall know you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nay brother.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I say they shall.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Let me go down and wash my face first.

sp.speaker: Alex 〈…〉.
sp.l: Your face is a fine face my brother gentleman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Sir, you are victoriously welcome.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: That word has e'en conquered me.

sp.speaker: Li●●.
sp.l: I desire to kiss your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Indeed but you shall not sir, I went out early, and forgotten to wash 'em.

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: Precious dotterel .

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Sir, I shall call it a curtesy if you shall please to
vouchsafe to pledge me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: What is't brother four or six?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Four or six, 'tis rich canary, it came from beyond the seas.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I will do no courtesy at this time sir, yet for one cup I care not, because it comes from beyond the seas.
sp.l: I think 'tis outlandish wine.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.l: Look how it glides.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now truly the gentleman drinks as like one master Widgen a kinsman of mine.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Pox on ye hilding.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I ha' heard of that widgeon, I ha' been taken for him, and now I think on't, a cup of this is better than our four shilling beer at home.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: You must drink another sir, you drunk to nobody .

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is it the law, that if a man drinks to nobody , he must drink again.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ay, ay, I. Fill his glass.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why, then I will drink to nobody once more, because I will drink again.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Did I not tell ye. More wine there drawer.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.l: This pageant's worth the seeing by this hand.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: methinks this glass was better than the tother gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: O sir, the deeper the sweeter ever.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Do ye think so?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Ever that when ye drink to nobody .

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why then I pray give me tother cup that I may drink to somebody .

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: I have not drunk yet sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Again ye witch? drink to the young gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Mistress Lindabrides.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.l: Thanks most ingenious sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: She's a little shame faced, the deeper the sweeter forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Pox on ye for a coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.p: I'th next room I have seen and heard all. — o noble soldiers.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Here boys, give us some more wine. There's hundred marks gallants. 'tis your own. And do but let me bear on office amongst ye. I know as great a matter has been done for as small a sum. Pray let me follow the fashion.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Well, for once take up the money, give me a cup of sack. And give me your hand sir, and because our Flemish corporal was lately choked at Delft with a flap-dragon. Bear you his name and place, and be henceforth called corporal codshead. Let the health go round.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Round. And this go not round. Some wine there tapster. Is there never a tapster i'th house?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My worthy friend, thou art master of thy word, gentlemen 'tis ancient young, you're soldiers, come come, save cap, compliment in cup. Prithee sit down.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Are you a captain sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: And you a lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: I pray where served you last?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Why, at the battle of Prague.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Under what colonel. In what regiment?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, let me see: but come in company: let's sit sir. True soldiers scorn unnecessary discourse, especially in taverns.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: 'Tis true, true soldiers do: but you are tavern-rats.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Prithee.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Foul food that lies all day undigested,
Upon the queasy stomach of some tavern,
And are spewed out at midnight.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Corporal codsheads health sir.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: In thy face fool.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: This is a cruel ancient.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Ye are but the worms of worth,
The sons of shame and baseness,
That in a tavern dares outsit the sun,
and rather than a whore shall part unpledged,
You'll pawn your souls for a superfluous cup,
Though ye cast it into the reckoning,
The true soldier, who is all o'er, a history of man,
Noble, and valiant, wisdom is the mould,
In which he casts his actions, such a discreet temperance
Doth daily deck his doings, that by his modesty,
He is guessed the son of merit, and by his mildness
Is believed valiant, go, and build no more
These airy castles of hatched fame, which fools
Only admire and fear you for, the wiseman
Derides and jeers ye puffs really of
Virtue and valour? (These fair twins
That are born, breath and die together) then
You'll no more be called butterflies, but men:
Think on't, and pay your reckoning.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Shall we suffer this Saunder?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I must go after him.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Kill him, and there be no more men in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.p: I know my sister loves him, and he swears he loves her, — and by this hand, it shall go hard if he have her not, smock and all, brave excellent man, with what a strength of zeal we admire that goodness in another, which we cannot call our own. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: He's a dead man I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: But where's our corporal, corporal, corporal?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, here's your corporal, and youLooks outcan be quiet.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Look and he have not ensconced himself in a wooden castle?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Is he gone that called us butterflies?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Yes, yes, has taken wing, and your brother's gone after him, to fight with him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
That's well, he cannot in conscience but do us the courtesy and kill him for us, come gallants, what shall we do? I'll never go home to go to bed with my guts full of four shillings beer, when I may replenish them with
sack, — hay, now am I as lusty, methinks we two have blue beards, is there ne'er a wench to be had? Drawer bring us up impossibilities, an honest whore, and a conscionable reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Why here's all fire, wit, where he will or no.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Ah whore, o tempting, handsome sir, think of a rich wife rather.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tempting handsome sir, she is not married is she gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A woodcock springed, let us but keep him in this Bacchanalian mist till morning, and 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Tempting handsome sir, I have known a woman of handsome tempting fortunes, throw herself away upon a handsome tempting sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Hark you sir, if she had, and could be tempted to't, have you a mind to marry: would ye marry her?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: O, and a man were so, worthy tempting sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Give me but a piece from you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: And when will you give it me again?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Pray give me but a piece from you, I'll pay this reckoning into th' bargainagain, and if I have not a trick to make it your own, I'll give you ten for't — here's my witness.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: There 'tis, send thee good luck with't, and go drunk to bed.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Do not you be too rash, for she observes you, and is infinitely affected to good breeding.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I wonot speak I tell you, till you hold up your finger, or fall a whistling.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, we'll pay at bar, and to the mitre in Breadstreet, we'll make a mad night on't, please ye sweet ladies but to walk into Breadstreet, this gentleman has a foolish sleight supper, and he most ingenuously professes, it would appear to him, the meridian altitude of his desired happiness, but to have the table decked with a pair of perfections, so exquisitely refulgent.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: He talks all sack, and he will drink no small beer:

sp.speaker: Bawd
sp.l: Pray lead, and he shall follow.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.l: Bless mine eyes, my heart is full of changes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O, is it so, I have heard there be more changes in a woman's heart in an hour, then can be rung up on six bells, seven days, well go thy ways, little dost thou think how thou shalt be betrayed, within this four and twenty hours, thou shalt be mine own wife, flesh and blood, by father and mother, o tempting handsome sir.

div.head: Actus. 3. Scaena. 1.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: But sirrah, canst tell what my mistress means to do with her suitors?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I know not, but there is one of them I am sure worth looking after.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Which is he, I prithee?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O John, master Randall, John.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The Welshman.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: The witty man, the pretty man, the singing man, he has the daintiest ditty, so full of pith, so full of spirit, as they say.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Ditties, they are the ends of old ballets.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Old ends, I am sure they are new beginnings with me.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Here comes my mistress:

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Who was that knocked at 'Gate?

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Why your Welsh wooer.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Alas, the sight on's eyes enough to singe my little maidenhead , I shall never be able to endure him.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: When high King Henry, second ruled this land,
The couple of her name,
Besides her Queen, was teerely loved,
A fair and princely — widows,
sp.p: Hark you widows, Randalls was disturbed in cogitations, about lands, ploughs, and cheese presses in Wales, and begar her have forgotten where her, and her meet soon at pright dark evenings.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Why on the change, in the Dutch walks.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: O haw, have her — but Randalls was talk no Dutch, pray meet her in the Welsh walk, was no Welsh walk there?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Fie, no, there are no Welsh merchants there.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Mas, was ferry true, was all shentlemen in Wales, her never saw her shamber-maid, pray where was her shamber-maid?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Taken up i'th kitchen sir.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Can her make wedding pedd pravely for Randalls, and widows?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Pray tell him Jarvis where she can or no.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Sir, not to delay, but to debilitate the strength of your active apprehension of my mistress favour.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Was ferry good words.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Hark in your ear, she will have her nest feathered with no British breed.

sp.speaker: Randall.
sp.p: Zounds, was not Prittish so good as English?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Yes, where there's wisdom, wit, and valour, but as amongst our English, we may have one fool, a knave, a coxcomb, and a coward, she bid me tell ye, she has seen such wonders come out of Wales in one shirt, you're an ass, and she'll have none of you

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Augh, s. Tavie, Owen Morgan, and all her cousins, was widow herself say so?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Good sir, let every circumstance make up one answer, take it with you.

sp.speaker: Jaruis.
sp.p: And the Roman answer is, the English goose sir.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p:
Sounds, her was kill now, gog, and Gogmagog, a whole dozen of shiants, make fool of Randalls, Randalls was wished to as brave match as widows was, know one Mary Bloodhound,
was ha all, when her father kick up heels, and begar though her never saw her, her will send her love letters presently, get her good wills, and go to shurch and marry, and her were eight and thirty, two hundred and nine and fifty widows, mark her now.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: He pelts as he goes pitifully.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Where's Mary?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Marry.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray go to Algate, to my sempstress for my ruff, I must use it say too morrow, did ye bid her hollow it just in the French fashion cut?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: 'Twas well, we have no other proof in use, that we are English, if we do not zany them, let John go with you.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Yes forsooth:

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: But pray forsooth, how do you mean to dispose of your suitors?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Shall I tell thee, for this thou hast given him this cure, and he is past care, for old Bloodbound the saw-monger, I writ to him, to meet me soon at ten in the dark, upon the change, and if I come not by ten, he should stay while twelve, intimating something mystically, that to avoid surprisals of other rivals, I mean to go from thence with him to lie at his house all night, and go to church with him i'th morning, when my meaning is only knavery, to make myself merry, and let him cool his heels there till morning.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: And now have I a whimsy, newly jumped into the coll of ingenious apprehensive, to sauce him daintily, that for that, what think ye of the gentleman that brought a stool with him out of the hall, and sat down at dinner with ye in the parlour?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: They say he's an ancient, but I affect not his colours.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: But what say ye to the mad victorious Alexander?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: A wild mad roarer, a trouble not worth minding.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He will mind you ere morning: troth mistress there waits a gentleman i'th next room, that hath a long time loved you, and has watched for such an hour, when all was out of doors, to tell you so; and none being within but you and I, he desires you would hear him speak, and there's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: An honest man.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: How know ye?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Why, he told me so.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And why were you such a fool to take his own word?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Because all the wit I had could get nobody's else.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: A knave will ever tell you he's an honest man.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: But an honest man will never tell you he's a knave.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Well sir, your mistress dares look upon the honest man.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: And the honest man dares look upon my mistress. Exit.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: 'Tis the roughest bluntest fellow.
sp.p: Yet when I take young Bloodhound to a retired collection of scattered judgement, which often lies disjointed, with the confused distraction of so many: methinks he dwells in my opinion, a right ingenious spirit, veiled merely with the vanity of youth and wildness: he looks methinks like one that could retract himself from his mad starts, and when he pleased turn tame: his handsome wildness methinks becomes him, could he keep it bounded in thrift and temperance: but down these thoughts, my resolve rests here in private, — but from a fool, a miser, and a man too jealous for a little sweetness love, Cupid defend me.

div.stage: Enter like a gentleman very brave with Jarvis clothes in's hand.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: And to a widow wife,
nobly liberal, and discreetly credulous,
Cupid hath sent me.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray prove as you appear a gentleman. Why Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Look ye here's Jarvis hangs by geometry, and here's the gentleman. For less I am not that afar off taken with the sainted praises of your wealthy beauty, your person, wisdom, modesty, and all that can make woman gracious, in this habit sought and obtained your service.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: For heaven's sake what's your intent?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I love you.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Pray keep off.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I wood keep from you. Had my desires bodies
How I could beat them into better fashion,
And teach them temperance, for I rid to find you;
And at a meeting amongst many dames,
I saw you first: o how your taking eyes,
Those active sparkling sweet discovered twins,
In their strong captivating motion, told me
The story of your heart, a 1000 Cupid's
Methought sat playing on that pair of christails,
Carrying to the swiftness of covetous fancy,
The very letters we spell love with.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Fie. Fie.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I have struck her to the heart, through my face
Apparelled with this field of gravity,
The neglected roughness of a soldier's dart.
sp.p: These diamond pointed eyes but hither through, and you will see a young spring on't, but question times fair ones.
They'll confess, though with a blush they have often found good wine at an old bush. My blood is young, and full of amorous heats, which but branched out into these lusty veins,
sp.l: Wood play, and dally, and in wanton turnings
Wood teach you strange constructions.
sp.p: Let time and place then with love's old friend opportunity instruct you to be wise.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Alas sir, where learned you to catch occasions thus?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Of a lawyer's clerk wench, that with six such catches, leapt in five years from his desk to his coach drawn with four horses.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Do ye mean marriage?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Marriage a cloying meat, marry who thou wilt to make a show to shroud thee from the storms round headed opinion, that sways all the world, may let fall on thee. Me cousin? thou shalt call once in a month, or so: I'll read false letters from a far distant uncle, insert his commendations to thee, hug thy beleeuing husband into a pair of handsome horns. Look upon him with one eye, and wink upon thee with tother. Wouldst have any more?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: The return of servants, or some friendly visit will intercept us now: reassume your habit, and be but Jarvis till tomorrow morning, I now by the potent truth of friendship, I will give you plenty of cause to confess I love you truly, and strongly.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: You're in earnest.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: On my life serious, let this kiss seal it.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: The softest wax ever sealed bawdy business.
sp.p: Now for old Bloodbound, I will meet you upon the change sir, with a blind bargain, and then help your son to a good pennyworth: this night shall be all mirth, a mistress of delight. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bloodhound, Earelacke with letters, Sim, and Moll.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, mark what follows, I must bring her home dark, turn her up to bed, and here she goes to church: my cloak sirrah.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: 'Tis a very dark night sir, you will not have a cloak for the rain.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I am going to steal the widow from I know not how many.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, than I let your cloak for the rain alone, and fetch you a cloak for your knavery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: To bed, to bed — good son, what Sim I say.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I charge ye let not one be up ith' house, but yourself, after the clock strikes ten, nor a light be stirring, Moll, trick up the green bedchamber very daintily.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And well remembered Moll, the keys of my compting house, are in the left pocket of my hose above i'th wicker chair, look to them and have a care of the black box there I have often told thee of, look to that as to thy maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Pray for me all, pray for me all.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Have you left out any thing for supper?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Out rogue shall not I be at infinite expense tomorrow, fast too night, and pray for me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: An old devil in a greasy satin doublet, keep you company.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I say, the satin doublet you will wear too morrow, will be the best in the company sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: That's true, that's true, I come widow, I come wench.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O sweet Sim, what shall I do tomorrow, tomorrow must be the day, the doleful day, the dismal day, alas Sim, what dost thou think in thy conscience I shall do with an old man?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, you're well enough served, you know how your brother not an hour ago, lay at you to have the ancient, one that your ●eeth●e'ne water at, and yet you cry, I cannot love him, I wonot have him.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I could willingly marry him, if I might do nothing but look on him all day, where he might not see me, but to he with him, alas I shall be undone the first night.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: That's true, how will you go to bed else, but remember he is a man of war, an ancient, you are his colours, now when he has nimbly displayed ye, and handsomely folded ye up against the next fight, than we shall have you cry, o sweet Sim, I had been undone, if I had not been undone.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay, and then the old fellow would mumble me to bed.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: A bed, a bawd with two teeth would not mumble bacon, so then he so sparing you, shall wear nothing, but from the brokers at second hand, when being an ancients wife, you shall be sure to flourish.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Prithee go in and busy the old man with a piece of Reynard the fox, that he may not disturb us, for at this hour I expect ancient young, and my brother.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Well, I leave you to the managing of ancient young, while I go in and flap the old man i'th mouth with a fox tail. Exit.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Look, look, and he have not brought him just upon the minute, o sweet silken ancient, my mind gives me, thee and I shall dance the shaking of the sheets together.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Now, you mistress fig-tail, sahe wind come about yet, I ha' brought the gentleman, do not you tell him now, you had rather have his room than his company, and so show your breeding.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Now fie upon you, by this light you're the wickedest fellow, my brother but abuses you, pray sir go over again, you've a handsome spying wit, you may send more truth over in one of your well penned pamphlets, than all the weekly news we buy for our penny.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Pox on't, I'll stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Sfoot thou shalt stay longer, we'll stay her heart her guts out.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Ha, ha, how will you do for a sister then?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Prithee Moll do, do but look upon him?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: ●●s, when I ha' no better object.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What canst thou see in him thou unhandsome hideous thing, that merits not above thee?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: What would I give to kiss him?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Has he not a handsome body, straight legged, a good face.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Yes, but his lips look as if they were as hard as his heart.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Foot, shall try that presently.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: You're basely sir conditioned, — pagh.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why, do you spit?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Ye may go by this light, he kisses sweetly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Do but stay a little Moll, prithee Moll, thou knowest my father has wronged him; make him amends and marry him.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Sweet m. Spendall spare your busy breath,
I must have a wise man, or else none.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And is not he a wise man?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Because he keeps a fool company.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Why, you are now in's company.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: But birds of a feather will fly together, and you and he are seldom asunder.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why you young witch, call your elder brother fool; but go thy ways, and keep thy maidenhead till it grow more deservedly despised, then are the old base boots of a half stewed pander: lead a Welsh morris with the apes in hell amongst the little devils, — or when thou shalt lie sighing, by the side of some rich fool, — remember thou thing of thread and needles, not worth three pence half penny.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Too late I fear I ha' been too coy, you are to be married then sir?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: I am indeed sweet mistress, to a maid
Of excellent parentage, breeding, and beauty.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I ha'thought of such musicians for thee.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: But let it not be any way distasteful unto you, that thus I tried you, for your brother persuaded me to pretend love to you, that he might perceive how your mind stood to marriage, in that (As I guess) he has a husband kept in store for you.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ay, I have provided a husband for thee Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: But I'll have no husband of your providing, for alas now shall have the old man whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I have such a stripling for thee, he wants one eye, and is crooked legged, but that was broke at football.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Alas, we cannot mould men you know.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: He's rich, he's rich Moll.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Ha'him and his riches good sir, you're to be married in earnest.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: In earnest; why, do ye think men marry as fencers sometimes fight, in jest?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Shall I show her mistress Elizabeth's letter I snatched from thee?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Not, and thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Good brother let me see't, sweet brother, dainty brother, honey brother.

sp.speaker: Alex
sp.p: No indeed, you shall not see't, sweet sister, dainty sister, honey sister.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O good sir, since so long time I have loved you, let me not die for your sake.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The tide turns.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Long time loved me?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Long ere you went to sea I did.
I have loved you very long with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Think of Bess; think of Bess, 'tis the better match.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Ye wicked brother, indeed I love you better, than all the Besses in the world, and if tonight I shift not into better fortunes, tomorrow I am made the miserablest wife marriage and misery can produce.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Alas sir, I am to marry an old man, a very old man, trust me, I was strange in the nice timorous temper of a maid, I know against our sex to say we love, but rather than to match with sixty and ten, threescore and ten times I wooed tell you so, and tell them ten times over too, truth loves not virtue with more of virtuous truth, than I do you, and wonot you love me then? Weeps.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: And lie with thee too by this hand wench, come let us have fair weather, thou art mine, I am thine, there's an end of the business, this was but a trick, there's the projector.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: O you're a sweet brother.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And now thou'rt my sweet sister, I know the old man's gone to meet with an old wench that will meet with him, or Jarvis has no juice in's brains, and while I i'th mean time, set another wheel a going at the widows, do thou soon about ten, for 'tis to be very conveniently dark, meet this gentleman at the nag's head corner, just against Leaden-hill, we lie in Lime-street, thither he shall carry thee, accommodate thee daintily, all night with mistress Dorothy, and marry thee i'th morning very methodically.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: But I have the charge of my father's keys, where all his writings lie.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: How all things jump in a just equivalency, to keep thee from the thing of threescore and ten, didst thou not see my mortgage lately there?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Stay, stay.

sp.speaker: Alex
sp.l: A white devil with a red fox tail, in a black box.

sp.speaker: Mol
sp.p: But yesterday my father showed it me; and swears if I pleased him well, it should serve to jump out my portion.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Prove thine old dad a prophet, bring it with thee wench.

sp.speaker: Moll
sp.p: But now at's parting, he charged me to have a care to that, as to my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why, fine have thy maidenhead and that into the bargain, thy charge is performed, away, get thee in, forget not the hour, and you had better fight under ancient Young's colours, than the old man's standard of sixty and ten. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Remember this, madbrain.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter sue, Tim, captain, and bawd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, grandmother, I'll tell thee the best jest.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.l: Prithee chick.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Jest kether, here will be jesting of all sides I think, if Jarvis keep his word.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sirrah, whilst thou wert sent for into the next room, up came our second course, amongst others in a dish of blackbirds, there lay one, that I swore was a woodcock, you were at table captain.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That I was, and our brave mad crew, which for my sake you were pleased to make welcome.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pish, we'll have as many more tomorrow night, but still I swore 'twas a woodcock: she swore 'twas a backbird, now who shall we be tried by, but sergeant sliceman, captain Carveguts' cousin here, a trifling wager, a matter of the reckoning was laid, the sergeant swore 'twas a backbird, I presently paid the reckoning, and she clapped of the breast presently, and swore'twas a woodcock, as if any other wood pass after the reckoning was paid.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
