sp.l: This was a pretty one I protest.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Made sure before such a mad crew of witnesses, sirrah, Granham, all's agreed, Sue's —.

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Ay you may see, how you men can betray poor maids.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Do you hear corporal, yonder's sergeant sliceman, and the brave crew that supped with us have called for three or four gallons of wine, and are offering money.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How, prithee Granham look to Dab, do you two but hold them in a talk, whilst I steal down and pay the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Do't daintily, they'll stay all night.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's it I would have man, we'll make them all drunk, they'll never leave us else, and still as it comes to a crown, I'll steal down and pay it in spite of their teeth, remember therefore that ye make them all drunk, but be sure you keep me sober to pay the reckonings.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: O Jarvis, Jarvis, how I long till I see thee.

div.stage: Enter Mol Bloodhound, and Sim, with a letter,

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: There we must meet soon, and be married tomorrow morning, Sim, is't not a mad brother?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Yes, and I can tell you news of a mad lover.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: What is he in the name of Cupid?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why one master Randalls, a Welshman, I have had such a fit with him, he says he was wished to very wealthy widow, but of you he has heard much histories, that he will marry you, though he never saw you, and that the parboiled Aetna of his bosom, might be quenched by the consequent pastime, in the Prittish flames of his Prittish blood, he salutes you with that love letter.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: This is a mad lover indeed, prithee read it.

sp.speaker: Sim,
sp.p: Mas, has writ it in Welsh English, we had been spoiled else, for want of an interpreter, but thus he begins, mistress Maries.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: He makes two Maries serve one mistress?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ever while you live, 'tis your first rule in weleh grammars, that her forsake widows, and take maids, was no crete wonder, for sentlemen ever love the first cut.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: But not o'th coxcomb, he should have put in that.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The coxcomb follows by consequence, mark else. I Randall crack, of Carmarden, do love thee Mary ploodbounds, of Houndsditch, dwelling Aulgate, and Pishops gate, just as between hawk and buzzard.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: He makes an indifferent wooing,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And that her loves maryes so monstrous, yet never saw her, was because her hear her in all societies so ferry fillanously commended, but specially before one master pussy constables of her parish, who made herself half foxed by swearing by the wines, that Maries would be monstrous good marriages for Randalls.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Master busy it seems was not idle.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If Maries can love a prittaine of the blood of Cadwalader, which Cadwalader, was prutes great grandfather. Randalls was come in proper persons, pring round sillings in her pockets, get father's good will, and go to surch a Sunday, with a whole dozen of Welsh harps before her, so her rest her constant lovers, Randall William, ap Thomas, ap Tavy, ap Robert, ap Rice, ap Sheffery, crack.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Fie, what shall I do with all them?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why, he said, these all rest your constant lovers, whereof, for manner's sake, he puts himself in the first place; he will call here presently, will you answer him by letter or word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.l: Troth, neither of either, so let him understand.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Will ye not answer the lovesick gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: If he be sick with the love of me, prithee tell him, I cannot endure him, let him make a virtue of necessity, and apply my hate for's health.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ay, but I'll have more care of the gentleman I warrant you, if I do not make myself merry, and startle your midnight meeting, say Sim has no more wit than his godfathers, and they were both headmen of this parish.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.l: Farewell widows prove, her sall no Randalls have,
Widows was ferry full of wiles,
Mary bloodhounds now, Randalls make a vow,
Was run for Moll a couple of miles.

div.stage: Honest Simkins, what said mariee to Randals letters?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You're a mad man.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Augh, her was very clad her was mad.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: The old man has money enough for her, and if you marry her, as if your project take, you may, she'll take you more than a man.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: More than man's, what the?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Trough cannot you tell that, this is the truth on't, she wood be married tomorrow, to one ancient young a fellow she cannot endure, now she says, if you could meet her privately tonight , between ten and eleven, just at the great crossway, by the nag's head tavern at leaden-hall.

sp.speaker: Ran.
sp.p: Was high, high pump, there as her turn into grace's street.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: There's the very place, now because you come the welcomest man in the world to hinder the match against her mind with the ancient, there she will meet you, go with you to your lodging, lie there all night, and be married to you i'th morning at the tower, as soon as you shall please.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Becat her will go and prepare priests presently, look ye Simkins, there is a great deal of round sillings for her, her was very lucky sillings, for came to Randalls shust for all the world as fortune was come to fool, tell maryes, her will meet her, her warrant her, make many puppy fools of ancients, and love her very monstrously. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, so, so, this midnight match shall be mine, she told me she was to meet the ancient there, I'll be sure the ancient shall meet him there, so I shall lie a-bed to laugh, to think if he meet her there, how she will be startled, and if the ancient meet him there, how he will be cudgeled, beware your ribs master Randall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p:
I wonder where this young rogue spends the day, I hear he has received my hundred marks, and my
advantage with it and it may be, he went home since I went out. Iaruis was with me but even now, and bid me watch, and narrowly, for fear of some of my rival spies: for I know she has many wealthy suitors, all love money. This Jarvis is most neat in a love business; and when we are married because many mouths much meat, I will requite his courtesy, and turn him away; the widow's all I look for. — nay, let her fling to see I have her possessions, there's a saw for't.
sp.l: There's thriving in wiving: for when we bury
Wives by half-dozens, the money makes marry.
O money, money, money, I will build thee
An altar on my heart, and offer to thee
My morning longings, and my evening wishes,
And hadst thou life, kill thee with covetous kisses.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: But now and she speak she spoils all, or if he call her by my mistress his name, hast thou no: tricks to enjoin them both to silence till they come sure.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Phaw, that's a stale one, she shall speak to him in her own accent, he shall call her by her own name leaving out the bawd, yet she shall violently believe he loves her, and he shall confidently believe the same which he requires, and she but presents. Enter mistress Coote.
sp.l: Fall off, she comes.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Here I have discovered him, 'tis he by his coughs, remember your instructions, and use few words, for though till tonight you knew it not, and will he married early in the morning, to prevent a vintner's widow, that lays claim to him.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Good old man, I know him by his tongue.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Is she come? is she come Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Ask her if she wood live sir, she walks a loose yonder.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: We shall cozen all her wooers.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p:
Nay, amongst all of you, we'll cozen one great one, that had laid a pernicious plot this night, with a cluster
of his roaring friends to surprise her, carry her down to the water side, pop her in at puddle-dock, and carry her to graves's end in a pair of oars.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: What, what is his name I prithee.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He's a knight abounding in deeds of charity, his name sir Nicholas name.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And wood he pop her in at puddle-dock?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: And he could but get her down there.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: By my troth we shall pop him fairly, where is she? where is she?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Ha, do you not perceive a fellow walk up and down muffled yonder?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: There is something walks.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: That fellow has dogged us all the way, and I fear all is frustrate.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Not I hope man.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: This 'tis to be in love, if I do not dwindle.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I know him now.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: 'Tis none of sir Nicholas spies, is't?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: He serves him.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: He wonot murder me, will he?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He shall not touch you, only I remember this afternoon, this fellow by what he had gathered by caves dropping, or by frequent observation, asked me privately if there were no meeting betwixt you and my mistress tonight in this place, for a widow he said he knew you were to meet.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Now I handsomely threw dust in's eyes, and yet kept the plot swift a foot too, I told him you were here to meet a widow too, whom you long loved, but would not let her know't till this afternoon, naming to him one of my ants, a widow by Fleet-ditch, her name is mistress grey, and she keeps divers gentlewomen lodgers.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Good again.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: To turn the sent then, and to cheat inquisition the more ingeniously.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And to bob sir Nicholas most neatly.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Be sure all this night studably in the hearing of any that ye shall but suspect to be within hearing to call her nothing but mistress Coote.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Or widow Coote.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Yes, you may put her in so, but be sure you cohere in every particle, with the precedent fallacy, as that you have loved her long, though till this day, and so as I did demonstrate.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: But how and she wooed say she is not widow come, and that she knows no such woman, and so spoil all?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Trust that with her wit, and my instructions we suspected a spy, and therefore she will change her voice.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Thou hast a delicate mistress of her.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: One thing more, and ye meet presently, mine aunt has had mine husbands, tell her you'll hazard a limb and make the tenth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Prithee let me alone, and sir Nicholas were here himself, he should swear 'twere thine aunt.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Go forwards towards him, be not too full of prattle, but make use of your instructions.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who's there, widow Coote?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Master Bloodbound as I take it.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: She changes her voice bravely, I must tell thee true widow, I have loved thee long time, look how the rogue looks, but had never the wit to let thee know it till today.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: So I was given to understand sir.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Is't not a fool finely?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Handsome by this hand.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I like thy dwelling well upon the fleet ditch.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: A pretty wholesome air sir, in the summer time.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who would think 'twere she Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I told ye she was tutored.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I'll home with her presently, some stays up i'th dark.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Fool and he have any private discourse with her, they discover themselves one to another, and so spoil the plot, no trick, no by no means sir, to hazard your person with her, the bold rogue may come up close to discover her to be my mistress, and recover her with much danger to you.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: He has got a dagger.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: And a sword six foot in length, I'll carry her home for you, therefore not a light be stirring; for I know your rivals will watch your house, Sim shall show us the chamber, we'll conduct her up ith' dark, shut the door to her above, and presently come down and let you in below.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: There was never such a Iaruis heard off, bid Sim to be careful, by the same token, I told him he should feed tomorrow for all the week after: good night widow, Coote my man stayeth up, we will bob sir Nicholas bravely. Good night sweet widow Coote. I do but seem to part, we'll meet at home wench. — Exit.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: Adieu my sweet dear heart.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Go you with me, so, so, I will cage this cuckoo, and then for my young madcap, if all hit right, this morning's mirth shall crown the craft o'th night, follow me warily.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I warrant thee Jarvis, let me alone to right myself into the garb of a lady: o strange to see how dreams fall by contraries, I shall be coached tomorrow, and yet last night dreamed I was carted: prithee keep a little state, go Jarvis. Exit

sp.speaker: Randall.
sp.p: Was ferry exceeding dark, but here is high pumps, sure here is two copy of cross ways, and there was the street where grace dwells, one hundred pound in mornings in round shillings, and wife worth one thousand ere her go to bed. Randalls fortunes comes tumbling in, like lawyer's fees, huddle upon huddle.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p:
O sweet ancient, keep thy word, and win my heart, they say, a moonshine night is good to run
away with another man's wife, but I am sure a dark night is best to steal away my father's daughter.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Mary.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: O, are ye come sir? there's a box of land and livings, I know not what ye call it.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Lands, and livings?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Nay, nay, and we talk, we are undone, do ye not see the watch coming up Gracious-street yonder, this cross way was the worst place we could have met at, but that is yours, and I am yours, but good sir do not blame me, that I so suddenly yielded to your love, alas you know what a match an't I should have tomorrow else.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Her means the scurvy ancient.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: I'th morning we shall be man and wife, and then, alas I am undone, the watch are hard upon us, got you back through Cornhill, I'll run round about the change, by the church corner: down cat-eaten street, and meet you at Bartholomew lane end. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Cat's street was call her, sure Randalls was wrapped in mother's smock. Exit.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Keep straight towards Bishopsgate, I am deceived and I heard not somebody run that way.

div.stage: Enter chambermaid, Hugh with a band box.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: Stay sir, here's somebody come from aldgate-ward?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Alas, I shall be hanged for staying so long for this cuff.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Come before the constable here.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Let the constable come before me and he please.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: How, how, where ha' you been prey dame, ha?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.p: For my mistress ruff, at her seamstress sir, she must needs use it tomorrow, and that made me stay till 'twas done.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.l: Pray who's your mistress, where dwell ye?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: With one mistress wag in Blackfriars, next to the sign of the feathers and the fool sir.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: O, I know her very well, make haste home, 'tis late. Come, come, let's back to Gracechurch, all's well, all's well.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: I scaped the watch at Bishopsgate with ease, there is somebody turning down the church corner towards the exchange, it may be mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: Ancient.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Are ye here again, you have nimbly followed me; what said the watch to ye?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: I passed them easily, the gates are but now shut in.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: As we go, I'll tell you such a tale of a Welsh wooer, and a lamentable love-letter.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Yes, Sim told me of such a rat, and where he lodges, I thought I should have met him here.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Here, out upon him: — but the watches walk their station, and in few words is safety, I hope you will play fair, and lodge me with the maid ye told me of.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: She stays up for us wench, in the word of a gentleman, all shall be fair and civil.

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.l: I believe you.

div.stage: Enter at several doors Randalls and maid.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Zounds was another fire drake walk in shange, we'll run pack, mass maryes have saved her labours, and was come after Randalls, maryes was Randall that loves her mightily maryes.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Master Randall.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: How did watch let her go at grace's street?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: They knew me, and let me pass.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p:
Well now, her understands maryes loves Randalls
so mighty deal.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: If John have not told him, I'll be hanged.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Maryes shall go with Randalls to lodgings, and that her father work no divorcements, he will lie with her all t'night, and marry her betimes next morning, mean time her will make lands and livings fast.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: How father? this is a mistake sure, and to fashion it fit for mine own following, I will both question and answer in ambiguities, that if he snap me any way, I may make myself good ith' tother, and as he shall discover himself, I'll pursue the conceit accordingly: but will ye not deceive me, many minds are many men's almanacs, the dates of your desire's out, we serve for nothing but to light tobacco.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: If Randall false to maryes prove,
Then let not maryes Randalls love:
For Randalls was so true as Jove,
And maryes was her joy.
If Randalls was not pritaine born,
Let maryes Randalls prow adorn.
And let her give a foul great horn to Randalls,
Her will love her cret deal of much her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: And 'tis but venturing a maidenhead, if the worst come to the worst, it may come back with advantage. Exit.

div.stage: Enter in her night-clothes, as going to bed widow and maid.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Is not Mary come home yet?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: No forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: 'Tis a fine time of night, I shall thank her for't, 'tis passed eleven I am sure. Fetch, the prayer-book lies within upon my bed.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p:
I wonder what this gentleman should be
that catched me so like Jarvis, he say he has fitted old Bloodhound according to his quality — but I must not let him dally too long upon my daily company, lust is a hand-wolf, who with daily feeding, one time or other takes a sudden start upon his benefactor.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: O mistress, mistress.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What's the matter wench?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: A man, a man under your bed mistress.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: A man, what man?

sp.speaker: Maid:
sp.p: A neat man, a proper man, a well-favoured man, a handsom man.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Call up John, where's Jarvis?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Alas, I had no power to speak, his very looks are able to make a woman stand as still as a miller's horse when he's lading, o he comes, he comes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: How came you hither sir? how got you in?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As citizens wives do into masks, whether I wooed or no nay, nay, do not doubt the discretion of my constitution: I have brought never a groat in my bosom, and by this hand, I lay under thy bed, with a heart as honest, and a blood as cold, as had my sister lay near top — will ye have me yet?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You are very rude, uncivil fellow.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Uncivil, and lay so tame while you set up your foot upon the bed, to untie your shoe, such another word, I will uncivillize that injured civility which you so scurvily slander, and reward you with an undecency proportionable to your understandings, will ye have me, will you marry me?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: You, why tomorrow morning I am to be married to your father.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: What, to sixty, and I know not how many, that will lie by your side, and divide the hours with coughs, as cocks do the night by instinct of nature.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: And provide for his family all day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And only wish well to a fair wife all night.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.l: And keep's credit all day in all companies.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And discredit himself all night in your company.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Fie, fie, pray quite my house sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: ●oars, 'tis my house.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.l: Your house, since when?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Even since I was begotten, I was born to't , I must have thee, and I will have thee, and this house is mine, and none of thine.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: O mistress, the saddest accident i'th street yonder.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What accident prithee?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: You must pardon my boldness, into your bedchamber, there is a gentleman slain in a fray at the door yonder, and the people wonot be persuaded, but that he that did it, took this house, there is the constable, churchwardens, and all the headmen of the parish, be now searching, and they say they will come up hither to your bed chamber, but they'll find him, I'll keep them down as long as I can, I can do no more than I can. Exit.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Are not you the murderer sir?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: I ha' been under thy bed by this hand this three hours.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Pray get you down then, they will all come up, and find you here and all, and what will the parish think then? pray get you down.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: No, no, no; I will not go down now I think on't.Makes himself unready.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Why, what do you mean, you will not be so uncivil to unbrace you here?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: By these buckles I will, and what they will think on't —

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Alas, you will undo me.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: No, no, I will undo myself look ye.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Good sir, I will off with my doublet to my very shirt.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Pray sir have more care of a woman's reputation.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Have a care on't thyself woman, and marry me then.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Should they come up and see this: what could they think, but that some foul uncivil act of shame had this night stained my house, and as good marry him as my name lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Alexand.
sp.p: Will you have me afore tother sleeve goes off?

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Do, hang yourself, I will not have you — look, look, if he have not pulled it off quite, why you wonot pull off your boots too will you?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Breeches and all by this flesh.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: What, and stand naked in a widow's chamber.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As naked as Grantham steeple, or the strand maypole by this spur, and what your grave parishioners will think on't?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Gentlemen pray keep down.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.p: Alas, they are at the stair's foot, for heaven's sake sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Will you have me?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: What shall I do? no.

sp.speaker: Alex,
sp.p: This is the last time of asking, they come up, and down go my breeches, will you have me?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay, alas, and your breeches go down
I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Why then kiss me upon't, and yet there's no cracking your credit, Jarvis is come in, Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: I have kept my promise sir, you're catched the old one.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.l: How catched, is there nobody below then?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: nobody but John, for sooth, recovering a tobacco snuff, that departed before supper.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: And did you promise this sir?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: A woman cannot have a handsomer cloud, than a hare-brained husband: I will be your coz, he shall be my cuckold.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.l: I love ye for your art.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: Come, come, put on sir, I have acquainted ye both with your father's intended marriage, i'th morning you shall certify him very early by letter, the quality of your fortunes, and return to your obedience, and that you and your wife, still concealing the parties, will attend him to church, John and I'll be there early, as commanded by my mistress, to discharge our attendance: about goes the plot, out comes the project, and there's a wedding dinner dressed to your hands.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: As pat as a fat heir to a lean shark, we shall hunger for't, honest Jarvis, I am thy bedfellow tonight , and tomorrow thy master.

sp.speaker: Vvid.
sp.l: You're a fine man to use a woman thus?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Pish, come, come, fine men must use fine women thus, 'tis fit, plain truth takes maids, widows, are won with wit.

sp.speaker: Jarvis.
sp.p: You shall wear horns with wisdom, that is in your pocket.

div.head: Actus 5. Scaena. 1.
div.stage: Enter Sim, and John, passing over with a basin of rosemary, and a great flagon with wine.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Come John, carry your hand steadily, the guess drop in a pace, do not let your wine drop on't.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p:
'Tis as I told thee, master Alexander, thy mistress
eldest son will be here.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Rose, I pray burn some pitch i'th parlour, 'tis good against ill airs, master Alexander will be here.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I am up before ye son Earelack, will ancient young be here with a rich wife too? thy mistress is not stirring yet sirrah, I'll hold my life the baggage slip to thy mistress, there they have e'en locked the door to them, and are tricking up one another: o these women! but this rogue Tim, he lay out tonight too, he received my hundred mark, and I fear is murdered: truss, truss, good Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He has been a-wooing sir, and has fetched over the delicat'st young virgin, her father died but a week since, and left her to her marriage, five thousand pound in money, and a parcel of land, worth three hundred perannum.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis like, the boy had ever a captivating tongue to take a woman — o excellent money, excellent money, mistress of my devotions, as if my widow's estate is little less too, and then Sander, he has got a monied woman too, there will be a bulk of money, Sim is puling sir, I may tell thee, one that by nature's course, cannot live long: tother, a midnight sunset cuts off, then have I a trick to cozen both their widows, and make all mine, o Jarvis, what a monied generation shall I then get upon thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: A very virtuous brood.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Hast done?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: I have done sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I'll in and get some music for thy mistress, to quicken her this morning, and then to church in earnest, 'tis done, where is sir Nicholas Nemo and his words that watch so for her? Ha, ha, ha, all's mixed with honey, I have mirth, a sweet young widow and her money, o that sweet saint, called money.

div.stage: Enter Alexander, widow, ancient, Moll and Sim.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Joy I, and a 100 pound a year in a black box to the bargain given away i'th dark last night, to we know not who, and to be heard of we know not when. Sfoot and this be joy, wood we had a handful, some slice of sorrow to season it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: By this light 'twas strange.

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Believe me sir, I thought I had given it you, he that took it called me by my name.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Did he speak Welsh or English?

sp.speaker: Moll.
sp.p: Alas, I know not, I enjoined him silence seeing the watch coming, who parted us.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: If this were not master Randalls of Randall hall that I told ye of, I'll be flayed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Be masked, and withdraw a while, here comes our dad.

div.stage: Enter Bloodhound, sir Marmaduke many minds, sir Janus Ambodexter, and master busy.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Why master busy, asleep as thou standst man?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Some horse taught him that 'tis worth god a mercy.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I watch all night, I protest sir the counters pray for me, I send all in cut and long tail.

sp.speaker: Sir marma.
sp.l: What, what?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: I sent twelve gentlewomen, our own neighbours last night, for being so late but at a woman's labour.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Alas sir, a woman in that kind you know must ha' help.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: What's that to me? I am to take no notice of that, they might have let her alone till morning, or she might have cried out some other time.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: Nay, nay, master busy knows his place I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Son Alexander welcome, and ancient young to, I have heard all.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: You must pardon the meritable rudeness of the gentlewomen sir, in not unmasking, they entreated me to inform you: there are some ith' house to whom they wood by no means be laid open.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: They are witty, they are witty.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: But for myself, I am now your most obedient virtuous Alexander.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Obedience, hang her virtue, let her starve; has she money? hath she money?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Two chests of silver, and two utropian trunks, full of gold and jewels.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: They are all Alexander's women, do ye mark?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Alexander was the conqueror sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Come, come, we'll to church presently: prithee Jarvis whilst the music plays just upon the delicious close, usher in the brides, the widow, and my Moll.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I tell ye true gallants, I have seen neither of them today. Shall I give him the lie?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: They are both locked up i'faith, trimming of one another. O these women, they are so secret in their business, they will make very coxcombs of us men, and do't at pleasure to, 'tis well said friends, play, play, where's Sim?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: How he bestirs him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes, he will sweat by and by.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Here is the sign of Sim sir.

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.l: Have the guest's rosemary without?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They have risen the cookmaid without, but they say you have mistress Mary within.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Well said rascal.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Marie's above goodman blockhead. Call my son Earelack, bid him for shame make haste.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: He shall make haste for shame.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: I am so busied, you must bear with me gentlemen, they leave it all to me here.

sp.speaker: Coast
sp.p: But I will go charge some of the inferior guess in the King's name to fill some wine.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: No, no, good master busy, we will first usher the brides.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: O gentlemen, where are you? where are you?
Where are you gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Where's Moll Sim, the widow Sim, the dainty widow?

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.p: There is no Moll, there is no dainty young widow, but a damnable bawd we found a-bed with a face like an apple half roasted.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Why gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Now it works.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Jarvis you're a rogue, a cutpurse Jarvis, run Sim, call my son Earelack, he shall put her into the spiritual court for this.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay, has put her in there already, for we found him a-bed with her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Possible.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha boys, the informer and the bawd, the bawd and the informer have got a devil betwixt them gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay sir, the jest was, that they should fall asleep together, and forget themselves, for very lovingly we found them together, like the jemini, or the two winter mornings met together: look, look, look where they come sir, and Jarvis between them, just like the picture of knavery, betwixt fraud and lechery.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: Tim is a puling sirrah, I may tell it thee, a midnight surfeit too may cut off Sander, I'll cozen their wives, make all mine own, and then, o Jarvis what a moneyed generation shall I get, upon this widow Coote that hath two teeth.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Did we bring you to music with a mischief Earlack? thou art a goat, thou hast abused the best bed in my house, I'll set a sumner upon thee.

sp.speaker: Earla.
sp.p: Bloodhound, thou art a usurer, and takest forty in the hundred, I'll inform against thee.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Are you a bawd housewife, ha?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Alas sir, I was merely envied, betrayed by Jarvis, but as I have been bawd to the flesh, you have been bawd to your money; so set the hare pie against the goose giblets, and you and I are as daintily matched as can be sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sim, run to the widow wags, tell her we are both abused, this Jarvis is a juggler, say.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: I can save Sim that labour sir, I assure you the widow is married to your son Alexander, and as a confirmation she is come herself to witness it. Discovers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Your fair young daughter is wife to this ancient, who is come likewise to witness it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: The plain truth is master Bloodhound, I would entreat you to keep the kennel, the younger dog being of the better sent, has born the game before ye.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: We have clapped hands on't sir, and the priest that should have married you to her, is to marry her to me, so sister, talk for yourself.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha brave tricks and conceits, can ye dance master Earelack?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Ha, ha: the old man's a little mad: but thou art not married Moll?

sp.speaker: Mol.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, and will lie with this gentleman soon at night: do you think I wood chew ram mutton, when I might swallow venison, that's none of Venus' documents monsieur Dottevill?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Pox of that Venus, she is a whore I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: And were not you the tother juggler with Jarvis in this, heigh pass and repass.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p:
Good sir be satisfied, the widow and my sister sung both one song, and what was't, but crabbed age and youth cannot live together. Now we persuaded them, and
they could not live together, they wood never endure to lie together, this consequently descended, there was the antecedent, we clapped hands, sealed lips, and so fell unto the relative,

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: This was your bargain upon the exchange sir, and because you have ever been addicted to old proverbs, and pithy saws, pray let me seal up the mistake with one that will appear very seasonably.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: And I pray let's hear it sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: You, a new fangled fowler, came to show your art i'th dark, but take this truth, you catched in truth a cuckoo for't. Enter Tim.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Heyday, we are cheated by the rule i'faith, now sirrah, they say you are to be married too.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Yes indeed father, I am going to the business, and gentlemen all, I am come whether you will or no, to invite ye all to my marriage, to this gentlewoman, who though a good face need no mask; she's masked to make a man think she has a scurvy face, when I know she has a good face, this is sack to them and out of their element.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: But sirrah, setting aside marriages, where's my hundred mark you went to receive?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hum, upon such a match of mine, talk of a hundred mark, this is to drink ignoble son shillings beer, a hundred mark, why your lawyer there can clear such a trifle in a term, and his clients never the better.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Such a match, I pray discover her, what is she?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What is she, here's my brother knows what she is well enough, come hither Dab, and be known unto you, her name is Lindabrades, descended from the emperor Tribatio of Greece, and half niece, some six and fifty descents to most unvanquished Claridiana.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Who's this? pox on't, whatUnmasks her.makes that bawd yonder?

sp.speaker: Bussy.
sp.p: I am very much deceived, and I did not send this gentlewoman very drunk tother night to'th counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I tell thee prattling constable, 'tis a lie, Lindabrades a drunkard?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Hark ye brother, where lies her living?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Where, why in Greece.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: In grease.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She looks as if she had sold kitchenstuff.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: This is a common whore, and you a cheated coxcomb, come hither, you rotten hospital, hung round with greasy satin, do not you know this vermin?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: I winked at ye sue, and ye could have seen me, there's one Jarvis, a rope on him has juggled me into the suds too.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Now I know her name too, do not you pass under the name of Sue Shortheels, minion?

sp.speaker: Sue.
sp.p: Go look master little wit, will not any woman thrust herself upon a good fortune, when 'tis offered her?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Sir Marmaduke, you are a justice of peace; I charge ye in the King's name, you and master Ambodexter, to assist me with the whore and the bawd, to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Sir Mar.
sp.p: By my troth and we will, by that time we shall have an excellent stomach by that time dinners ready.

sp.speaker: Ambodex.
sp.l: Ay, ay, away with them, away with them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.l: O this rogue Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Now, now, you look like a melancholy dog, that had lost his dinner, where's my hundred marks now you coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Truly father, I have paid some sixteen reckonings, since I saw you, I was never sober since you sent me to the devil yesterday, and for the rest of your money, I sent it to one captain Carvegut, he swore to me his father was my lord mayor's cook, and that by easter next, you should have the principal, and eggs for the use indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Blood
sp.p: O rogue, rogue, I shall have eggs for my money, I must hang myself.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Not afore dinner pray sir, the pies are almost baked. Enter rand.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: And maryes now was won, and all her pusiness done, and Randalls now was run, her have made all sure I her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Alexand.
sp.p:
Look, look, yonder's the conceit, the
mistake happened upon last night.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: And the very box at's girdle.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Cot pless her father Bloodhounds, Randalls have robbed ancients her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Sir 'tis known how you came by that box.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Augh was her so, will hear an noble prittaine, how her gull an English flag?

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: And you ought to cry.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: O noble Randalls, as her meet by nagshead with mayres blood, brave.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Here's another madman.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Hark in your ear, you must deliver that box to me.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Hark in her tother ear, her will not deliver her, and her were nine and forty ancients, and five and fourscore flags.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.p: Let my foe write mine epitaph, and if I tear not my birthright from thy bosom?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Gentlemen, there's alicant i'th house, pray set no more abroach.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Nay let her come with her pack of needles, Randalls can pox and bob, as well as her, her warrant her.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: What box is that? I should know that box.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: I will resolve ye sir, keep them asunder.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: You will restore that box?

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Her will not restore her, 'twas Mary Bloodhounds gave her the box, Randalls have married Mary Bloodhounds and guled ancients, mark her now.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Mark him good sir, methinks he says he has married Mary Bloodhound.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Hang him, he's mad!

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: 'Zounds, make tog of Randalls? come out here maries.
Look here was Mary Bloodhounds. Enter maid and Hugh. now, I pray tumble down of her marybones, and ask her father blessing?

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: This, why this is your maid widow,

sp.speaker: Eare.
sp.l: This is Mary the widow's maid man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: And here is Mary Ploodhound, my choleric shred of Cadwallader, married to this gentleman, who has a hundred a year dangling at your girdle there.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: I pray mistress are you married to this gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: By six i'th morning forsooth, he took me for Mary Ploodhound, having it seems, never seen any on's before, and I being something amorously affected, as they say to his Welsh ditties, answered to her name, lay with him all night, and married him this morning, so that as he took me for her, I took him as he was forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: She means for a fool, I am fain to answer for you.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Cupid this twenty four hours has done nothing but cut cross capers.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Do ye hear, sir Bartholomew Bayard, that leap before ye look, it will handsomely become you, to restore the box to that gentleman, and the magnitude of your desire, upon this dainty, that is so amorously taken with your ditties.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Her wail in woe, her plunge in pain.
sp.p: And yet begar her do not neither, Randalls will prove herself Prittaines born, and because her understands ancients was brave fellows, and great travellers, there is her box for her.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: And because was no remedies, before her all, here will Randalls embrace maries, and take a puss —Kisses.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Save ye gallants, do ye want any guess?
Call me thy coz, and carry it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Who have we here trow?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Dost thou know the gentleman that whispered to thee?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: O wondrous well, he bid me call him coz, and carry it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Widow, wood I were off again.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: Know all, this gentleman has to obtain his lust, and loose desires, served me this seven months, under the shape and name of Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Possible?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Look well, do ye not know him?

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: The very face of Jarvis.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I truly father, and he were any thing like him,
I would swear 'twere he.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: I must cast my skin; and am caught — why coz.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Come you're cozened,
And with a noble craft, he tempted me
In mine own house, and I bid him keep's disguise
But till this morning and he should perceive,
I loved him truly, intending here before ye,
To let him know't, especially i'th presence
Of you sir, that intend me for your wife.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: What should this mean?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Some witty trick I warrant thee, prithee dispatch him presently, that we were at church.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: First, then know ye for truth sir, I mean never to marry.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How woman?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: She has dispatched you sir.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.p: And for a truth sir, know you, I never mean to be your whore.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: But true, as she whose chaste immaculate soul,
Retains the noble stamp of her integrity,
With an undefaced perfection — perchance as these
Nay common fame, hath scattered you, conceive me,
Because pale jealousy (Cupid's angry fool)
Was frequent lodger at that sign of folly;
My husbands soon suspicious heart, that I
In a close clouded looseness, should expose him
To that desperate distraction of his fortunes,
That sent him to the sea, to nourish her,
With your vain hope, that the fame of frequent suitors,
was but a mask of loose scapes, like men at lotteries:
You thought to put in for one sir, but believe me,
You have drawn a blank.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.l: Became her look ferry black indeed,

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: O my beloved husband,
However in thy life, thy jealousy
Sent thee so far to find death, I will be
I will be married to nothing but thy memory.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: But shall the pies be spoiled then?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Let her alone, if her husband do not know this.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.l: Her husband I told you was a madman.

sp.speaker: Antient
sp.l: Why her husbands dead sir.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.p: He is not dead sir, he had it spread a purpose, he is in England, and in your house, and look: do ye not see him?

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: Where, where?

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Here, here he is that hath found rash jealousy,
Loves joys, and a wife whose discreet carriage
Can intimate to all men a fair freedom.
And to one be faithful, such a wife I prove,
Her husband's glory worth a wealthy love.

sp.speaker: Widow
sp.l: You are welcome to my soul sir.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: By my troth master wag this was a wag's trick indeed, but I knew I know ye, I remembered you a month ago, but that I had forgotten where I saw you.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I knew you were a crafty merchant, you helped my master to such bargains upon the exchange last night: here has been the merriest morning after it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: My pitchers broke just at the well head, but give me leave to tell you sir, that you have a noble wife, and indeed such a one as wood worthily feast the very discretion of a wise man's desire, her wit ingeniously waits upon her virtue, and her virtue advisedly gives freedom to her wit, but because my marriage shall seriously proceed, I wed myself sir to obedience, and filial regularity, and vow to redeem in the duty of a son, the affection of a father.

sp.speaker: Rand.
sp.p: Becat was as well spoken as Randall herself could talk.

sp.speaker: Blood.
sp.p: All is forgotten now my best son Alexander, and that my wedding want no good company, I invite you all.

sp.speaker: Iar.
sp.l: Come my deserving wife,
Wisdom this day remarries us. And gentlemen
From all our errors we'll extract this truth,
Where vicious ends prepose, they stand on wheels,
And the least turn of chance throws up their heels:
But virtue's lovers ever green do last,
Like laurel which no lightning can blast.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
